THE WEST POINT INVASION
AST year, a confident Army lacrosse team charged their way
to a 5 to 3 victory on Homewood Field. While a pouring rain
Oinked the spectators in the stands, Harry Wilson and his West
Point comrades battered away at the Jay defense. Finally, in the
second half, Hopkins' resistance to the onslaught was broken. Led
by Wilton, the Army stickmen plowed through the mud to score a
clean-cut win. With that loss, the Jays' hopes of representing Amer;
ica in the Olympics sank to a low ebb.
.Tomorrow, when the Jays invade the West Point battle-field,
they will be seeking revenge. Army, on the other hand, should also
be in fine fighting form. After losing to St. John's, the military college stickmen will be out for blood at the expense of the Hopkins
team.
• To date, the record of the HomewoOd outfit has been most en,
couraging to supporters of the Jays. By keeping the 'opposition
scoreless in two games, the defense has given a rare exhibition of

L

skill. Corner Brownley, at goal, has proven a worthy successor to
Ray Finn. Although not as strong as the defense, the attack has
maintained a steady bombardment against the opposition's goal. However, when they face the Cadets tomorrow, the Blue Jays will experience their first important test of the new season. After the
Army battle, it will be possibfe to give a fair estimate of the poten
nalities of the new twelve.,
-When the Jays depart • for the north, they will take with them
the best wishes and moral support of the entire student body.

. THE "DOCTOR'S" DILEMMA
HEN the average American citizen hears the 'word,

Johns
Hopkins, he immediately conjures. up the vision of a medical school and hospital. He sees white,elad surgeons carving out
appendixes, nurses-in stiffly starched linen, patients in wheel chairs,
rows of beds, bewhiskered physicians, stacks of Medical books, labors''
tories filled with test tikes and walls covered with anatomical charts.
Since Johns Hopkins is a medical school, enaturally follows that all
students who attend Johns Hopkins are medical students.
Thus, on the average of once a week, the scholar who attends
the College. of Arts and Sciences is subjected to the following rather
disioncerting catechism:
-What are you doing
"Going to college.'
•

"Where"
• "Johns Hopkins.."Oh, I didn't know

you were going to be a doctor.Then, the poor unfortunate is forced to enter into a detailed discussion of the various departments of the University and conclude
his lecture with a statement of his life purpose. After receiving his
A. B. degree on graduation day, his remaining years will be dedi,cated to the selling of Washing machines rather than the removal of

• tonsils.
When will the world learn that the entire University is not
located on Wolfe Street and that all the graduates of Johns Hopkins
do not dedicate their lives to the medical professio57 When, prophet,
will that Golden Day crime?

THE HIGH COST OF EATING
ITH the formation of the coat line at the New Howard
Hotel, last night, another banqUet season passed into history. To the upper clansmen who had witnessed the sensationa
battle at Annapolis, the past season may have seemed a trifle tame.l
There were no last minute embarkations from Pratt Street wharves.
There were no bills for broken china or splintered furniture.. The
police patrols were left in the garages and the night magistrates were
faced by no collegiate criminals.
The past mew was certainly characterized by safety and sanity.
But the battle-scarred veterans of Annapolis, who still hear the sounds
of smashing china echoing in their ears, will never forget that two
column spread on the back page of the staid, old Baltimore Sun; the
raucous voice of the Mayor of Annapolis; hnd the strong arms of his
police force. Those were the days!

Gentlemen:
The tobacco samples you sent me

have been received,and they are great.
If you can picture in your mind the
lonesomeness of a traveling man in a
small town on a rainy night, not a
friend in a hundred miles, nothing to
do and no place to go:
That was the position I was in when
your samples of Edgeworth came. It
was like a voice from above when I
opened the package and got the old
pipe steaming.
I have smoked various brands of
tobacco for the past fifteen years, but
never in my life have I found a tobacco at any price that will equal
Edgeworth. It does not bite the
tongue, and a beautiful aroma follows.
With the good old friend pipe and a
can of Edgeworth you can dream of
the rainbow's end.
Please count me in the future as an

Edgeworth booster.
Very truly,
(Signed) Al Stanley

Dear Sir:
The editorial of April 16th, entitled "The Great Game of Politics"
makes good reading matter but
should provoke much comment due
to its American Mother Atmos!Mere. When I voted for-george
Gettemuller, I did so through no
great admiration for the gentleman
or his work but principally because
I like to see every student get a fair
deal and certainly Mr. Eldridge's
comments on Mr. Gettemuller were
most uncalled for. If Mr. Eldridge
disliked Mr. Gettemtiller's work, he
might have implied it without resorting to such strong terms. In
other words, he made it too evident
that he was doing the electing and
not the Junior Class. It was this
resentment on the part of the Class
of '30 that elected Mr. Gettemuller.
I think Mr. Gettemuller will take
his position seriously and prove
that the underdog isn't always the
startling failure that some people
would make him.
Speaking of politics, your NEWSLETTER most certainly advocates a
great system when it suggests that
the election of officers for the following year be conducted by the
Hullabaloo staff—which, of course,
would be very unprejudiced!
"A Country 13umpkin."

THE WEST POINT INVASION
AST year, a confident Army lacrosse team charged their way
to a 5 to 3 victory on Homewood Field. While a pouring rain
Oinked the spectators in the stands, Harry Wilson and his West
Point comrades battered away at the Jay defense. Finally, in the
second half, Hopkins' resistance to the onslaught was broken. Led
by Wilton, the Army stickmen plowed through the mud to score a
clean-cut win. With that loss, the Jays' hopes of representing Amer;
ica in the Olympics sank to a low ebb.
.Tomorrow, when the Jays invade the West Point battle-field,
they will be seeking revenge. Army, on the other hand, should also
be in fine fighting form. After losing to St. John's, the military college stickmen will be out for blood at the expense of the Hopkins
team.
• To date, the record of the HomewoOd outfit has been most en,
couraging to supporters of the Jays. By keeping the 'opposition
scoreless in two games, the defense has given a rare exhibition of

L

skill. Corner Brownley, at goal, has proven a worthy successor to
Ray Finn. Although not as strong as the defense, the attack has
maintained a steady bombardment against the opposition's goal. However, when they face the Cadets tomorrow, the Blue Jays will experience their first important test of the new season. After the
Army battle, it will be possibfe to give a fair estimate of the poten
nalities of the new twelve.,
-When the Jays depart • for the north, they will take with them
the best wishes and moral support of the entire student body.

. THE "DOCTOR'S" DILEMMA
HEN the average American citizen hears the 'word,

Johns
Hopkins, he immediately conjures. up the vision of a medical school and hospital. He sees white,elad surgeons carving out
appendixes, nurses-in stiffly starched linen, patients in wheel chairs,
rows of beds, bewhiskered physicians, stacks of Medical books, labors''
tories filled with test tikes and walls covered with anatomical charts.
Since Johns Hopkins is a medical school, enaturally follows that all
students who attend Johns Hopkins are medical students.
Thus, on the average of once a week, the scholar who attends
the College. of Arts and Sciences is subjected to the following rather
disioncerting catechism:
-What are you doing
"Going to college.'
•

"Where"
• "Johns Hopkins.."Oh, I didn't know

you were going to be a doctor.Then, the poor unfortunate is forced to enter into a detailed discussion of the various departments of the University and conclude
his lecture with a statement of his life purpose. After receiving his
A. B. degree on graduation day, his remaining years will be dedi,cated to the selling of Washing machines rather than the removal of

• tonsils.
When will the world learn that the entire University is not
located on Wolfe Street and that all the graduates of Johns Hopkins
do not dedicate their lives to the medical professio57 When, prophet,
will that Golden Day crime?

THE HIGH COST OF EATING
ITH the formation of the coat line at the New Howard
Hotel, last night, another banqUet season passed into history. To the upper clansmen who had witnessed the sensationa
battle at Annapolis, the past season may have seemed a trifle tame.l
There were no last minute embarkations from Pratt Street wharves.
There were no bills for broken china or splintered furniture.. The
police patrols were left in the garages and the night magistrates were
faced by no collegiate criminals.
The past mew was certainly characterized by safety and sanity.
But the battle-scarred veterans of Annapolis, who still hear the sounds
of smashing china echoing in their ears, will never forget that two
column spread on the back page of the staid, old Baltimore Sun; the
raucous voice of the Mayor of Annapolis; hnd the strong arms of his
police force. Those were the days!

Gentlemen:
The tobacco samples you sent me

have been received,and they are great.
If you can picture in your mind the
lonesomeness of a traveling man in a
small town on a rainy night, not a
friend in a hundred miles, nothing to
do and no place to go:
That was the position I was in when
your samples of Edgeworth came. It
was like a voice from above when I
opened the package and got the old
pipe steaming.
I have smoked various brands of
tobacco for the past fifteen years, but
never in my life have I found a tobacco at any price that will equal
Edgeworth. It does not bite the
tongue, and a beautiful aroma follows.
With the good old friend pipe and a
can of Edgeworth you can dream of
the rainbow's end.
Please count me in the future as an

Edgeworth booster.
Very truly,
(Signed) Al Stanley

Dear Sir:
The editorial of April 16th, entitled "The Great Game of Politics"
makes good reading matter but
should provoke much comment due
to its American Mother Atmos!Mere. When I voted for-george
Gettemuller, I did so through no
great admiration for the gentleman
or his work but principally because
I like to see every student get a fair
deal and certainly Mr. Eldridge's
comments on Mr. Gettemuller were
most uncalled for. If Mr. Eldridge
disliked Mr. Gettemtiller's work, he
might have implied it without resorting to such strong terms. In
other words, he made it too evident
that he was doing the electing and
not the Junior Class. It was this
resentment on the part of the Class
of '30 that elected Mr. Gettemuller.
I think Mr. Gettemuller will take
his position seriously and prove
that the underdog isn't always the
startling failure that some people
would make him.
Speaking of politics, your NEWSLETTER most certainly advocates a
great system when it suggests that
the election of officers for the following year be conducted by the
Hullabaloo staff—which, of course,
would be very unprejudiced!
"A Country 13umpkin."

Thegreat moment may come at a"modernistic"
symphony for piccolo and factory whistle,or it
might arrive in a tobacco shop—that glorious
instant when the healthy citizen boots out polite
pretense and announces, "Enough is enough!
Give me music I can understand; give me a
cigarette I can really taste, or stop the show!"
You can't blame him. Cigarettes, like music,
are supposed to give pleasure; if they don't

they're flat, and that's all there is to it.
Now, Chesterfields are made for the express
purpose of satisfying the taste. They have the
requisite mildness, but not carried to the vanishing point. Starting with the finest tobaccos
we can buy, we've added a blend that keeps
the best of their flavors intact.
That's the whole story, of which the happy
ending is, "I'd rather have a Chesterfield!"
